english_translation: Narrated by Rabi' ibn Harash: Rabi' ibn Harash was informed that his brother had died, so he hastened to where his brother lay. He sat at his head, supplicating for him and seeking forgiveness for him. Then he uncovered his face, and his brother said: "Peace be upon you. I have come before my Lord after you, and I was welcomed with mercy, fragrance, and a Lord who is not angry. He clothed me with garments of silk and brocade. I found the matter easier than what you suppose. But do not speak. Carry me, for I made a covenant with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ that he would not depart until I reach him."

english_translation: Narrated by Rabi' ibn Harash: His brother al-Rabi' became severely ill and was heavily afflicted. He said: I went away to attend to some need of mine and then returned. I said: What has happened to my brother? They said: Your brother has been taken. I said: Indeed we belong to Allah and indeed to Him we return. I entered and found him covered with cloth and lying on his back as is done with the dead. I ordered his washing and shrouding. While I was doing that, he moved the cloth thus and uncovered his face, then he returned as the best he had been. He had previously been severely ill. He said: Peace be upon you. I said: And upon you be the mercy of Allah. He said: Glory be to Allah! Is it after death, O my brother? He said: I have met my Lord after you, I was welcomed with mercy and fragrance, and a Lord who is not angry. He clothed me in green garments of silk and brocade. I found the matter easier than what is in your souls. And do not be beguiled, for I have asked permission from my Lord to give you glad tidings. Carry me to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, for he promised me that he would not precede me until I catch up with him. By Allah, I did not compare his death after his speech except to a stone that I threw into water and it disappeared.
